prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I stop giving my boyfriend blowjobs?
So i (21f) have been with my boyfriend (21m) for almost two years. I love him very much and we have a pretty stable relationship. There’s only one problem- he doesn’t go down on me. When I first started dating bf he told me he didn’t like giving head because of a bad experience with a girl (smelly vag). I thought fair enough and didn’t want to push him into something he’s not comfortable with. Fast forward and in the two years we’ve been together he’s gone down on me a total of 8 times. For a while there I actually forgot vaginal oral sex existed. Last week his friends were drunk and discussing how often they give head, which is almost always. I felt a bit bummed after hearing this, so asked bf the next day if there was something wrong with my lady bits and is that why he hardly ever does it. I keep things pretty clean and tidy down there and have never had any odour issues, so I figured maybe it doesn’t look normal and that’s why. He responded that he doesn’t even mind, he just doesn’t like doing it cause he “gets nothing out of it”. Which is a damn far cry from his original excuse. This made me really angry. I go down on him all the time. I think he’s being extremely selfish. The whole point of oral is to pleasure your partner, you don’t get anything out of it but the enjoyment of getting them off. I’ve been stressing out that somethings wrong with me or that he’s traumatised from a bad experience, but the whole time he just doesn’t want to do it because he’s selfish and only wants to do stuff that gets him off. Oral should be reciprocated and I’m annoyed at myself for letting him put his pleasure above mine. Ever since I’ve stopped giving him head, cause I’m sick of choking on dick and getting “nothing out of it”. I’m planning on bringing it up with him again tomorrow, if he refuses to compromise I don’t think I can ever go down on him again unless it’s reciprocated. I don’t know where our relationship will be if that’s the result. All I know is that I’m angry I’ve been lied to and treated like my pleasure is secondary. So reddit, WIBTA if I stop giving blowjobs and potentially damaging an otherwise decent relationship all because I want head?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, so I need to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. Let me read through the situation again carefully. 

The author is a 21-year-old woman in a two-year relationship with her boyfriend. He doesn't give her oral sex and has only done it eight times in two years. He initially gave an excuse about a bad experience (smelly vag), but now he says he just doesn't get anything out of it. The author is upset because she feels her pleasure is secondary. She stopped giving him blowjobs and is considering cutting them off unless he reciprocates. The question is, is she in the wrong?

First, let's consider consent and mutual satisfaction in a relationship. Healthy relationships require both partners to feel satisfied and respected. If one partner is consistently not fulfilling the other's needs without valid reasons, that could be a problem. The boyfriend changed his excuse from a past trauma to just not wanting to reciprocate. The author felt lied to, which adds to the tension. 

The boyfriend's behavior might be selfish if he's only focused on his own pleasure. The author's response is to stop giving blowjobs as a form of protest. Is that fair? Well, if both partners are supposed to reciprocate, then the author's demand for reciprocation makes sense. She's not just stopping for revenge but because she values mutual pleasure. 

However, communication is key. The author did talk to him again, and if he refuses to compromise, then the situation is out of her hands. But the initial act of stopping blowjobs could be seen as a consequence for his behavior, not just a selfish act. 

On the other hand, some might argue that stopping oral sex could be seen as using sex as a bargaining chip. But in this case, the author is trying to establish mutual respect and reciprocity, which is a valid relationship standard. 

So, is she in the wrong? If the relationship requires mutual effort and the other person isn't meeting their partner's needs, then the author's actions are justified. She's addressing a legitimate concern in the relationship. Therefore, the answer would be B (No).
